questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: Which of following is less suggestive of an organic cause of mental illness? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Auditory Hallucination

 

Auditory hallucinations are predominantly associated with psychiatric conditions rather than organic brain disorders. While they can occur in organic conditions like severe intoxications or delirium, they are most commonly observed in mental health disorders such as schizophrenia or severe depression. In contrast, organic causes of mental illness often involve symptoms that are related directly to physical changes or damage in the brain, such as those caused by neurological diseases, injuries, or infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Old age: Old age is not specifically indicative of an organic or non-organic mental illness but increases susceptibility to both, including neurodegenerative diseases.

 

Option B. Acute onset: Acute onset can often suggest an organic cause, especially when linked to brain injury or sudden health changes impacting brain function.

 

Option C. Loss of consciousness: Loss of consciousness typically points to an organic cause, as it can indicate underlying neurological issues or systemic body failures impacting brain function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with psychiatric illnesses and are less suggestive of an organic cause of mental illness compared to symptoms like loss of consciousness or acute neurological changes.

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of atypical depression? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased sleep: Individuals might sleep more than usual.

 

Option B. Reactive mood: While the individuals typically have a depressed mood, their mood can temporarily lift in response to positive events.

 

Option C. Heaviness of the body: Often described as "leaden paralysis," especially in the arms and legs.

 

However, the claim that atypical depression responds better to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) than to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) is incorrect. In reality, atypical depression often responds better to SSRIs & MAO-Is than to TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Atypical depression, as its name implies, has features that deviate from classic presentations of depression. It is characterized by reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight), presence of mood reactivity, leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection. SSRIs & MAO-Is have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 197.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: Which among the following is a symptom of cannabis intake? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dreamy State

 

Dreamy State is a symptom of cannabis intake.

 

CANNABIS INTOXICATION

 

  • Euphoria, sense of slowing of time, sense of floating in the air, reddening of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, dryness of mouth.
  • Depersonalization, Derealization, synaesthesia, illusions.
  • Bad trip- An unpleasant experience after consumption of cannabis in which the person may feel restless, fearful, paranoid and anxious.

 

CANNABIS WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS

 

  • Irritability
  • Depressed mood, sleep disturbances, headaches.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lorazepam + thiamine

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is displaying signs of alcohol withdrawal, particularly delirium tremens (DTs) which is characterized by confusion, visual and tactile hallucinations (like seeing snakes and feeling bugs crawling on the skin), tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.

 

  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal, including DTs.
  • Thiamine is essential to administer before or alongside glucose administration to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy in alcohol-dependent individuals.

  • Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 631-632.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

Let's match the descriptions to the terms:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

 

Abrupt discontinuation or dose reduction of venlafaxine has been known to result in a discontinuation syndrome characterized by agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. This is particularly noted with venlafaxine because of its short half-life. While all the drugs listed can have withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly, venlafaxine is particularly associated with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to seizure recurrence in those using it as an antiepileptic and can cause relapse of mood symptoms in those using it as mood stabilizer.

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Stopping it can result in a return of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option C. Imipramine: It can cause withdrawal symptoms, but they are typically more varied and might include headache, nausea, and malaise.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, often abbreviated as FINISH:

 

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Nausea
  • Imbalance
  • Sensory disturbances (e.g., electric shock sensations)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, agitation).

 

It is particularly common with SSRIs and SNRIs with shorter half-lives, such as venlafaxine (most common). Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Gradual tapering and patient education are essential to prevent and manage this syndrome.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3150.

questions.text: Patient with depression, which medicine is appropriate?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoxetine

 

Fluoxetine is an SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor) and is considered the first-line treatment for depression. SSRIs are preferred due to their efficacy and better side effect profile  compared to other classes of antidepressants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium: Lithium is primarily used in the treatment of bipolar disorder to manage both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication typically used for conditions like schizophrenia and delusional disorders.

 

Option D. Imipramine: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) and can be used to treat  depression. However, TCAs generally have more side effects and are less safe compared to SSRIs, making fluoxetine a more appropriate choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is the first-line treatment for depression due to its efficacy and favorable side effect profile.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia, and feelings of hopelessness. The patient has a history of a similar episode with full recovery approximately five years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent Depressive Disorder

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder (RDD) is diagnosed when a patient has experienced two or more depressive episodes, with each episode separated by at least two months of remission. In this case, the patient presents with symptoms of a current depressive episode and reports having experienced a similar episode five years ago, with full recovery in between. The presence of more than one depressive episode aligns with the criteria for Recurrent Depressive Disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Major Depressive Disorder: This would be considered if the patient was experiencing their first depressive episode. Since the patient has had a previous depressive episode, the diagnosis is Recurrent Depressive Disorder rather than a single Major Depressive Disorder.

 

Option C. Dysthymia: Also known as Persistent Depressive Disorder, dysthymia is characterized by chronic, mild depressive symptoms that last for at least two years. The patient's symptoms are more severe, consistent with major depressive episodes rather than mild chronic symptoms, which rules out dysthymia.

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: Cyclothymia involves periods of hypomanic symptoms and mild depressive (bipolar) symptoms over at least two years, but the symptoms do not meet the criteria for a full hypomanic episode or a full depressive episode. The patient's presentation does not include any hypomanic symptoms, making cyclothymia an incorrect diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder is diagnosed when a patient experiences two or more major depressive episodes, separated by periods of remission

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semantic memory: Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory: Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning: Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: A 42-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the emergency department with severe agitation, tremors, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 120/min, Temperature 39°C). Symptoms began 72 hours after his last drink. Laboratory findings show leucocytosis and elevated liver enzymes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delirium Tremens

 

This presentation is classic for Delirium Tremens (DT), characterized by:

  1. Onset 48-72 hours after last drink
  2. Severe autonomic instability
  3. Visual hallucinations
  4. Agitation and tremors
  5. Elevated vitals and temperature
  6. Occurs in context of alcohol withdrawal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's Encephalopathy: While also seen in alcoholics, it presents with the classic triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia/nystagmus rather than the severe autonomic symptoms seen here.

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This chronic condition presents with anterograde amnesia and confabulation, lacking the acute presentation and autonomic instability seen in this case.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: This is a delusional disorder characterized by beliefs of being loved by another person, unrelated to alcohol use or withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Delirium Tremens is a medical emergency with 5-25% mortality if untreated
  2. Onset typically 48-72 hours after last drink
  3. Key features: autonomic instability, hallucinations, tremors, agitation
  4. Treatment includes benzodiazepines, supportive care, and thiamine supplementation
  5. Risk factors include previous DT, long duration of heavy drinking, and concurrent illnesses

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: A person missing from home is found wandering purposefully. He is well-groomed and denies having any amnesia. Most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dissociative Fugue

 

Explanation:

 

Dissociative fugue is characterized by sudden, unexpected travel away from one's home or usual place of activities, with the inability to recall some or all of one's past. Individuals in a fugue state may adopt a new identity and appear well-groomed and purposeful. They often have no awareness of their amnesia during the fugue state, which aligns with the presentation described in the question.

 

Comparison Table for Dissociative Fugue and Dissociative Amnesia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dissociative Amnesia : Characterized by patchy memory loss without purposeful wandering or adopting a new identity. Patients are often aware of their memory gaps.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia : A mental disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking, and impaired functioning. Not typically associated with purposeful wandering and adopting a new identity.

 

Option D. Dementia : A decline in cognitive function, often with memory loss, but typically progresses over time and includes other cognitive impairments. Patients may wander but usually show signs of cognitive decline and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissociative fugue involves sudden, unexpected travel away from home with the adoption of a new identity and lack of awareness of amnesia during the fugue state.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

questions.text: During TURP, the surgeon takes care to dissect above the verumontanum to prevent injury to: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External urethral sphincter

 

Explanation:

 

The verumontanum, also known as the seminal colliculus, is an important anatomical landmark during Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP). It is crucial for the surgeon to avoid dissecting below this landmark to prevent damage to the external urethral sphincter, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. Injury to this sphincter can lead to complications such as urinary incontinence.

 

Key Anatomical Landmark in TURP:

 

 

The verumontanum serves as a critical stopping point for resection during TURP to avoid the external urethral sphincter and reduce the risk of post-operative complications related to urinary continence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral crest: The urethral crest is located within the prostatic urethra but is not as critical in the context of avoiding injury during TURP.

 

Option C. Prostatic utricle: The prostatic utricle is a small indentation in the prostatic urethra, but its injury is less consequential than that of the external urethral sphincter.

 

Option D. Trigone of the bladder: The trigone of the bladder is located within the bladder itself and is not relevant to the TURP procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During TURP, dissection above the verumontanum is crucial to prevent injury to the external urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic alcohol use was admitted with complaints of unsteady gait, difficulty in seeing, and appears confused. Which vitamin is he deficient in? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vit B1

 

The patient's symptoms of unsteady gait (ataxia), difficulty in seeing (ophthalmoplegia), and confusion (global confusion) are characteristic features of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine). The mnemonic "GOA" (Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia) is often used to remember the triad of symptoms associated with this condition.

 

Chronic alcohol use is a common cause of thiamine deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. The treatment involves administering high doses of parenteral thiamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vit B12: Deficiency of Vitamin B12 typically presents with symptoms such as anemia, glossitis, peripheral neuropathy, and in severe cases, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which does not match the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vit C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing, which are not observed in this patient.

 

Option D. Vit B3: Deficiency of Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with the triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. This does not align with the patient's symptoms of ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic GOA), is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) and commonly occurs in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

questions.text: A new IT employee is feeling guilty, miserable, and unable to concentrate on his task. His symptoms began three years ago, when he began college. The following is the most likely diagnosis: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysthymia

 

The patient's symptoms of guilt, misery, and concentration issues lasting three years are indicative of dysthymia (Persistent Depressive Disorder).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depressive disorder: At least 5 out of 9 symptoms should be present to diagnose depressive disorders which include: sad mood, loss of interest, guilt or worthlessness, lack of energy, poor concentration, increased or decreased appetite, increased or decreased psychomotor activity, increased or decreased sleep, and suicidal thoughts. The patient described above has only two of the above three symptoms. Patients with dysthymia have lesser symptoms and also the social occupational dysfunction is lesser in comparison to depressive disorder.

 

Option C. Adjustment disorder: It is characterized by emotional responses to stressful situations such as financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems etc. The symptoms range from anxiety to depressive symptoms. Symptoms usually last no longer than six months after removal of the stressor

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: It is a milder form of bipolar disorder, in which fluctuations between hypomania and mild depressive symptoms occur, but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania/hypomania or depression. The above described features do not mention any hypomanic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysthymia is characterized by chronic, less severe depressive symptoms lasting at least two years. Symptoms should not even be severe enough to meet the criteria of mild depressive disorder. (Subsyndromal depression >2 years duration). If the depressive disorder continues for more than 2 years, it is known as chronic depression.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world, his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him out of jealousy. His wife claims contrary, claiming that he has only recently begun acting in this manner, and that he previously worked calmly as a school teacher. He's probably suffering from? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world indicates a delusion of grandiosity. His belief that his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him due to jealousy represents a delusion of persecution. Both types of delusions are present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: Delusion of grandiosity is evident, but this choice doesn't encompass the persecutory beliefs he holds.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does display delusions of persecution, this choice neglects the grandiose delusion.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference: The patient clearly exhibits delusions of grandiosity and persecution, but there's no evidence in the provided information suggesting a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorders are characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 245-246.

questions.text:
A persistent alcoholic patient presents with convulsions and impaired sensorium. He has been drinking for ten years and consumes 24 units every day. His most recent drink was two days ago. He is discovered to have auditory hallucinations as well as secondary delusions. What method will you employ to manage this patient?

 

  1. Diazepam
  2. Thiamine
  3. Naltrexone
  4. Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, specifically delirium tremens, characterized by tremors, altered sensorium, hallucinations, seizures, and agitation.

 

1. Diazepam: Benzodiazepines, like diazepam, are the first line of treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms and can help reduce the severity of symptoms, prevent seizures, and can be titrated based on the severity of withdrawal.

 

2. Thiamine: Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is important to administer thiamine before or with the first dose of glucose-containing fluids or foods to prevent precipitating or exacerbating Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Naltrexone: This is an opioid antagonist that is used to decrease alcohol cravings. It is not directly useful in treating acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

4. Flupenthixol depot injection: This is an antipsychotic medication. It is not the primary treatment for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 472-473.

questions.text: A patient has the freedom to pick his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017. What is the name of this provision? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017 in India, the provision allowing a patient to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment is termed the “Advance directive”. It is a legal document wherein the individual specifies the type of treatment they want or don't want, should they become mentally ill and be unable to make competent decisions in the future.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment directive, Option B. Mental will, and Option C. Future directive are not the correct terms used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use and malnutrition presents with peripheral neuropathy, severe anemia, and glossitis. Recent blood tests show megaloblastic changes. Angular stomatitis and seborrheic dermatitis are also noted on examination. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

This clinical presentation is consistent with Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency, characterized by:

  1. Angular stomatitis (cracks at corners of mouth)
  2. Glossitis (inflammation of tongue)
  3. Seborrheic dermatitis
  4. Anemia
  5. Common in chronic alcoholism with poor nutrition

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): While common in alcoholics, thiamine deficiency primarily presents with Wernicke's encephalopathy (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) rather than the mucocutaneous symptoms seen here.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Although it can cause peripheral neuropathy, it doesn't typically cause the characteristic mucocutaneous manifestations seen in this case.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: While it can cause megaloblastic anemia and glossitis, the prominent dermatologic manifestations point more towards riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Vitamin B2 deficiency presents with characteristic mucocutaneous manifestations
  2. Common features include angular stomatitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis
  3. Often seen in context of chronic alcoholism and malnutrition
  4. Can contribute to anemia
  5. Treatment involves riboflavin supplementation and addressing underlying cause

questions.text: A patient was started on Amitryptiline and he was found to be unconscious. Which of the following doesn’t suggest TCA toxicity ?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

TCA toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia due to anticholinergic effects, not hypothermia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias: Arrhythmias are a hallmark of TCA toxicity, reflecting its impact on cardiac conductivity.

 

Option B. Confusion: Confusion or altered sensorium is common due to the central nervous system effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. Pupillary dilatation: Pupillary dilatation results from the anticholinergic properties of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of TCA toxicity, we see symptoms like arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilatation due to its anticholinergic and cardiotoxic properties. Hypothermia is not typically associated with TCA overdose.

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

The described clinical picture is consistent with Delirium tremens (DT). DT is a severe and potentially life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal. It typically appears 48 to 72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by agitation, disorientation, paranoid delusions, tremors, autonomic hyperactivity (such as tachycardia and hypertension), and visual or tactile hallucinations. It can be fatal if not treated promptly and properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. Symptoms include ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: It is a chronic neurologic sequelae of alcoholism resulting from prolonged thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and lack of insight.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: It is a rare complication where patients present with hallucinations after heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption but without other features of withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presented with fixed, false beliefs that his neighbors are spying on him through hidden cameras, recording his daily activities, and plotting to harm him. He has installed multiple locks on his doors and frequently checks for surveillance devices. Despite evidence to the contrary, he maintains these beliefs with complete conviction. What is the most appropriate management? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atypical antipsychotics

 

This patient presents with delusional disorder (persecutory type), for which atypical antipsychotics are the first-line treatment because:

  1. They effectively target fixed, false beliefs (delusions)
  2. Help reduce paranoid ideation
  3. Have better tolerability compared to typical antipsychotics
  4. Can improve insight and functioning
  5. Address the core psychotic symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioral therapy: While it may be helpful as an adjunct, it's not the primary treatment for delusional disorder, especially when insight is poor.

 

Option B. SSRI: SSRIs are not the first-line treatment for primary psychotic disorders. They may be used if there are concurrent depressive symptoms.

 

Option D. Supportive counseling: While important as part of comprehensive care, it's insufficient as primary treatment for delusional disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Delusional disorder requires antipsychotic medication as primary treatment
  2. Atypical antipsychotics are preferred due to better side effect profile
  3. Treatment often requires long-term medication
  4. Psychotherapy is adjunctive, not primary treatment
  5. Poor insight necessitates medication compliance monitoring

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

choices.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
Type 1 is common in both sexes
Attempt to commit suicide is seen around 15% of people

questions.text: Which of the following is false about bipolar disorder? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

 

Bipolar disorder, historically called manic-depressive illness, often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood. While it can start in childhood or later in life, this is less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 1 is common in both sexes: True. Bipolar I disorder has no gender bias and affects men and women equally.

 

Option C. Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%: True. Bipolar disorder affects about 1-2% of the global population.

 

Option D. Attempt to commit suicide is seen in around 15% of people: True. People with bipolar disorder have a high suicide risk, and approximately 15% may end up taking their own life.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar disorder typically presents in late adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by episodes of mania and depression, affects both sexes equally, has a prevalence of 1-2% in the general population, and carries a significant risk of suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 376.

questions.text: A patient is showing stubbornness and frugality. According to psychosexual stages of development, the fixation is in which stage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anal

 

According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which is no longer widely accepted, fixation at the anal stage can lead to certain personality traits in adulthood.

 

Individuals with anal fixation are said to be overly concerned with cleanliness, perfection, punctuality, and adherence to rules. They may exhibit stubbornness, frugality (not spending much and using minimal things), and a strong belief in their own rightness. The patient in this question displays stubbornness and frugality, which are characteristics associated with fixation at the anal stage of psychosexual development.

 

According to this theory, fixation at anal stage can cause OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral fixation is not associated with stubbornness and frugality.

 

Option C. Phallic fixation is not related to the given traits of stubbornness and frugality.

 

Option D. Genital fixation does not correspond to the characteristics mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which is no longer widely accepted, fixation at the anal stage is thought to cause personality traits such as stubbornness, frugality, obsession with cleanliness, perfection, punctuality, and adherence to rules. Anal fixation is also believed to potentially lead to obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) based on this theory.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of “feeling tensed” and having “stomach upset” symptoms, including heartburn and diarrhea. She states that she has been having these symptoms since she was 25 years old and that her family members are also usually tense and “nervous.” Which of the following symptoms are also likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tingling of extremities

 

The patient presents with symptoms of anxiety, including constant feelings of tension, gastrointestinal symptoms like heartburn and diarrhea, and a family history of similar symptoms, suggesting a diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). GAD often includes somatic symptoms, such as tingling of the extremities, due to hyperventilation or heightened nervous system activity associated with anxiety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideas of Reference: This symptom is typically associated with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia or delusional disorders, where the patient believes that events, objects, or other people have a special and personal significance. This is not characteristic of GAD.

 

Option C. Hallucinations: Hallucinations involve sensory perceptions without external stimuli and are common in psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia, but not in anxiety disorders.

 

Option D. Neologisms: Neologisms are newly coined words or phrases that have meaning only to the person using them and are commonly seen in formal thought disorders like schizophrenia. This is not a symptom seen in GAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) may experience somatic symptoms like tingling of extremities due to heightened anxiety and nervous system activity.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

The patient is experiencing oculogyric crisis, which is an acute dystonic reaction caused by antipsychotic medications. This is an extrapyramidal side effect that involves sustained, involuntary upward deviation of the eyes.

 

This is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It's commonly used as the first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions, including oculogyric crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: Useful for generalized dystonia or akathisia but not the first line for acute oculogyric crisis.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Another antipsychotic, it wouldn't directly treat the acute dystonic reaction.

 

Option D. Stop antipsychotic: While it might be necessary to review and adjust the antipsychotic regimen if a patient is having side effects, simply stopping the antipsychotic won't provide immediate relief from an acute dystonic reaction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

questions.text: A patient presented with hypertension, increased heart rate, and sweating. He sees red halos after hearing the radio. Which substance's abuse can cause this? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) LSD

 

The patient's symptoms include hypertension, increased heart rate, and reflex hallucinations (seeing red halos in response to auditory stimuli).

 

Reflex hallucinations occur when a stimulus in one sensory modality triggers a hallucination in another sensory modality, such as an auditory stimulus leading to a visual hallucination.

 

LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen known to cause such reflex hallucinations. Additionally, LSD can lead to sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Although cocaine can cause sympathetic symptoms such as hypertension and increased heart rate, it is less commonly associated with reflex hallucinations.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol abuse typically does not present with reflex hallucinations and the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes sedation and respiratory depression, not reflex hallucinations or sympathetic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

LSD, a hallucinogen, can cause reflex hallucinations, where a stimulus in one sensory modality (e.g., auditory) produces a hallucination in another modality (e.g., visual), along with sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought for psychiatric evaluation by his family. He consistently believes that he is superior to others, demands constant admiration, shows a strong sense of entitlement, and lacks empathy. Despite being in a junior position at work, he frequently boasts about his "exceptional abilities" and becomes angry when not given special treatment. His relationships are superficial and he exploits others for personal gain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Narcissistic personality

 

The presentation is characteristic of Narcissistic Personality Disorder, evidenced by:

  1. Grandiose sense of self-importance
  2. Preoccupation with fantasies of unlimited success
  3. Need for constant admiration
  4. Strong sense of entitlement
  5. Interpersonal exploitation
  6. Lack of empathy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antisocial personality: While there may be exploitation of others, the primary features here are grandiosity and need for admiration rather than disregard for social norms and rights of others.

 

Option C. Schizotypal personality: This disorder is characterized by odd beliefs, magical thinking, and eccentric behavior, none of which are present here.

 

Option D. Paranoid personality: While people with narcissistic personality may be suspicious of others, the primary features here are grandiosity and need for admiration rather than pervasive distrust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Narcissistic Personality Disorder involves a pervasive pattern of grandiosity and need for admiration
  2. Key features include sense of entitlement, exploitative behavior, and lack of empathy
  3. Different from antisocial personality which focuses more on violation of rights
  4. Treatment is challenging due to limited insight
  5. Often presents when narcissistic injuries occur (failures, rejections)

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3

 

The insight scale is graded from 1 to 5. In this scenario, the patient recognizes that there's something wrong with him mentally, which signifies some level of insight. However, he attributes it to the summer season, an external factor. This corresponds to a score of 3, which is recognition of a mental illness but blaming it on external causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Insight is graded from 1 to 5.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 967.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with seizures. On further evaluation, there was also a history suggestive of manic and depressive episodes. Which of the following drugs should be prescribed?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

The patient has a history of both seizures and bipolar disorder, characterized by manic and depressive episodes. Valproate (also known as valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant medication that is effective in treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder. It helps in stabilizing mood and preventing both manic and depressive episodes, making it an appropriate choice for patients with comorbid bipolar disorder and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregabalin: This drug is primarily used for neuropathic pain and certain anxiety disorders; it is not effective in the treatment of bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: This is an anticonvulsant used to treat seizures but does not have mood-stabilizing properties needed for bipolar disorder.

 

Option D. Levodopa: This is primarily used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and has no role in the management of seizures or bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Valproate is effective for treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder, making it the drug of choice for patients with comorbid conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is more common in Anorexia Nervosa when compared to Bulimia Nervosa? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Amenorrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Amenorrhea is more frequently associated with anorexia nervosa, primarily due to the effects of significant caloric restriction and weight loss on the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Starvation leads to a drop in GnRH, which lowers FSH and LH levels, resulting in decreased estrogen and subsequent menstrual irregularities or absence. While amenorrhea was once a diagnostic criterion in DSM-IV and ICD-10, it is no longer required in DSM-5 or ICD-11—but it remains a common clinical feature.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Dental Caries: More common in bulimia nervosa due to frequent self-induced vomiting. The repeated exposure of teeth to stomach acid leads to enamel erosion and caries—less typical in the restricting subtype of anorexia.
  • Option B. Antisocial Behavior: Neither disorder is primarily associated with antisocial traits. However, bulimia nervosa has stronger links to impulsivity and emotion dysregulation. In contrast, anorexia nervosa is often marked by control, rigidity, and perfectionism.
  • Option C. Craving for Food: Intense food cravings, particularly those leading to binge eating, are more characteristic of bulimia nervosa. While people with anorexia may think obsessively about food, they usually resist these urges rather than act on them.

 

Educational Objective:


Amenorrhea is a hallmark physiological consequence of the nutritional and hormonal imbalances seen in anorexia nervosa. Recognizing this and other subtle distinctions between anorexia and bulimia can help guide both diagnosis and management.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about behavior change stages and choose the correct answer :(INICET NOV 2023)

 

  • Statement 1: Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking.
  • Statement 2: Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walk considering its benefits to health.
  • Statement 3: Maintenance phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then.
  • Statement 4: Action phase – A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs in his family.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

The behavior change model, often based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM), outlines various stages individuals go through when changing a behavior as given below.

 

 

Statement 1: Correct. Contemplation involves thinking about quitting a behavior, such as smoking, which fits the scenario described.

 

Statement 3: Correct. The maintenance phase describes someone who has successfully sustained a behavior change, such as quitting smoking, over a long period.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Precontemplation is the stage where a person is not yet considering a change. In this case, considering starting a morning walk suggests the contemplation stage instead.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. This statement reflects a precontemplation attitude where the person is not considering change, attributed to a belief that obesity is inevitable due to family history, rather than being in the action phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct definitions of stages of behavior change is crucial in accurately assessing an individual's readiness to modify behaviors , based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM).

questions.text: A young male patient has been on 5 mg haloperidol for several days. However, he has been experiencing inner restlessness and a strong want to move for the past four days. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Akathisia

 

The patient is presenting with inner restlessness and a compelling desire to be in constant motion, which is consistent with akathisia. This is a common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia: Tardive dyskinesia is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect that can present as involuntary, repetitive movements of the tongue (e.g., twisting, protrusion), jaw (e.g., chewing also called. 

 

Option C. Rabbit syndrome: Rabbit syndrome lips (e.g., smacking, puckering), trunk and extremities.

 

Option D. Acute dystonia: Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotic and is characterized by sudden onset of muscle spasms, typically in the head and neck, occurring within hours to days of drug initiation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Akathisia is characterized by a sense of inner restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time. They can present soon after starting the antipsychotic or after dosage adjustments. It is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. Drug of choice is Propranolol (beta blockers).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 114

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pathological doubt

 

Pathological doubt is one of the most common symptoms in adult obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). People with OCD frequently doubt whether they've done something correctly, whether it's locking the door, turning off the stove, or other everyday tasks (obsession). This doubt leads them to repeatedly check or perform rituals to alleviate their anxiety (compulsion).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aggressive symptoms, Option B. Need for symmetry, and Option D. Sexual symptoms are also seen in OCD, but the constant doubt and resultant checking rituals are among the most characteristic and prevalent symptoms of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In adult OCD, most common presentation is obsession of contamination with compulsion of washing, followed by pathological doubt and checking rituals.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 96.

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sleep-onset insomnia

 

Melancholia, also known as melancholic depression, is a severe form of major depressive disorder characterized by specific symptoms. Key features of melancholia include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe anhedonia (a loss of pleasure in virtually all or almost all activities)

 

Option B. Weight loss

 

Option D. Profound feelings of guilt, often over minor or even imagined misdeeds.

 

The characteristic sleep disturbance in melancholia is early morning awakening, not sleep-onset insomnia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Melancholic depression refers to a depression characterized by severe anhedonia, early morning awakening, weight loss, and profound feelings of guilt. It is also associated with changes in ANS and endocrine functions, hence it is also known as ‘endogenous depression’.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380-382

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed

 

This is the classic test for immediate memory. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of digits (usually ranging from 5 to 9 numbers), and it tests the capacity of one's immediate memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps: This tests concentration.

 

Option C. Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed: This is more challenging than the forward span and is used to assess working memory.

 

Option D. Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps: Like the serial (100-7) test, it's more of an assessment for concentration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The digit span forward test, which involves repeating a sequence of numbers, is a measure of immediate memory and is a fundamental aspect of cognitive assessments.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 13.

questions.text: All of the following are disorders of perception, except: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion

 

Explanation:

 

Delusion is typically classified as a disorder of thought rather than a disorder of perception. It involves holding false beliefs that are not based on reality and are resistant to reason or confrontation with actual facts. Delusions can be seen in various psychiatric conditions, such as schizophrenia, but they do not involve the misinterpretation or false perception of sensory stimuli, which characterizes disorders of perception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Illusion: This is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus, such as seeing a shadow and thinking it is a person.

 

Option B. Hallucination: This is a perception that occurs without any external stimulus, such as hearing voices that are not there.

 

Option D. Depersonalization: This involves a feeling of detachment from one’s own body or thoughts, as if one is observing oneself from outside.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delusion is a disorder of thought, not a disorder of perception.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

  

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) primarily used as an antidepressant. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, enhancing its concentration in the synaptic cleft, which is beneficial in treating ADHD symptoms. Although it is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for ADHD, it can be prescribed off-label in certain cases due to its mechanism of action targeting norepinephrine, which plays a significant role in attention and impulse control.

 

Note – Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), used in treating ADHD, but not mentioned in option.

 

Other Options:
